授業方法: This class will be held face to face on campus in principle.  However, when there are students who cannot physically come to campus due to restrictive measures taken against the pandemic, class will be conducted in hybrid manner that combines interactive online schooling.  Documents and resources for the course will be uploaded on the website so that the students will have access to them when they join the class online.  (Please note that the situation of pandemic might necessitate a change of the Course Format.)

第1回:
（9/25）Introduction to the course: Understanding diversity and its critical importance for achieving SDGs (Miwa)
1) Objectives and focuses of the course
2) What is diversity in communities?
3) What is SDGs?
4) Who has a risk to be left out and why?

Required readings:
1) Transforming our world: the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development https://sdgs.un.org/2030agenda
2) The SDGs Report 2020
https://unstats.un.org/sdgs/report/2020/
3) Sustainable Development Report Rankings
https://dashboards.sdgindex.org/rankings
第2回:
（10/2）Introduction to gender (Miwa)
1) Understand the concept of gender.
2) Explore your gender awareness and experiences.

Required readings:
1) Gender Integration
https://www.ohchr.org/EN/Issues/Women/WRGS/Pages/GenderIntegration.aspx
2) UN Women Guiding Documents
https://www.unwomen.org/en/about-us/guiding-documents
第3回:
（10/9）Privilege and oppression: Opposite sides of the same coin (Deguchi)
1) Privilege: What is it, and how does it work?
2) Understanding structural oppression

Required readings:
Peggy McIntosh’s article:
1) McIntosh, P. (1989). White privilege: Unpacking the invisible knapsack. Peace and Freedom, July/Aug. pp10-12.
2) Coates, T. (2014). The Case for Reparations. https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2014/06/the-case-for-reparations/361631/
3) Strmic-Pawl, H. V. (2015). More Than a Knapsack: The White Supremacy Flower as a New Model for Teaching Racism. Sociology of Race and Ethnicity, 1 (1), 192–197.
第4回:
（10/16）Global commitment for gender equality and the empowerment of women (Miwa)
1) Understand historical development and change of focus of issues on gender.
2) Understand priority areas of the work on gender.

Required readings:
1) Turning Promises into Action
https://www.unwomen.org/en/digital-library/sdg-report
2) Planet 50-50 by 2030
http://www.unwomen.org/en/get-involved/step-it-up
3) HeForShe
http://www.heforshe.org/en
4) COVID-19 and Conflict: Advancing women’s meaningful participation in ceasefires and peace processes
https://www.unwomen.org/-/media/headquarters/attachments/sections/library/publications/2020/policy-brief-covid-19-and-conflict-en.pdf?la=en&vs=4621
第5回:
（10/23）Understanding the psychological dimensions of dominant group members (Deguchi)
1) What is race?
2) Theories of racial identity development
3) Becoming allies: Psychological processes of change for dominant group members

Required readings:
1) Sue, D. W., & Sue, D. (2013). White racial identity development model (Ch.12). Counseling the culturally diverse: Theory and practice. John Wiley & Sons
2) Sue, D. W., & Sue, D. (2013). Minority racial identity development model (Ch. 11). Counseling the culturally diverse: Theory and practice. John Wiley & Sons
3) Townsend, S. S. M., Markus, H. R., & Bergsieker, H. B. (2009). My Choice, Your Categories: The Denial of Multiracial Identities. Journal of Social Issues, 65(1), 185–204.
第7回:
（11/6）UN and disability (Nishino)
1) How disability has been regarded in international settings and the UN.
2) Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD)
3) Case study discussion. Students are expected to actively participate in group and class discussions.
第8回:
(11/13) Issues of SOGI/LGBTIQ (Miwa)
1) What kind of issues should be addressed?
2) Issues of “outing”
3) Issues of “micro aggression”

Suggested reading:
Protection against violence and discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity (SOGI)
https://documents-dds-ny.un.org/doc/UNDOC/GEN/N20/197/62/PDF/N2019762.pdf?OpenElement
第9回:
(11/20) Race, religion and ethnicity　(Kukita)
1) How does diversity create conflicts?
2) How can we prevent them and overcome differences?
3) Psychology of ethnocentrism, stereotype and prejudice
4) Social factors that affect ethnocentrism
5) Self-analysis of ethnocentrism
6) Apartheid: Systematic disempowerment of people, Namibian experience
第10回:
(11/27) Identity and conflict (Kukita)
1) What is identity
2) Identity and violence
3) Post-conflict identity development

Amartya Sen, “Identity and Violence: The Illusion of Destiny”, W.W. Norton, USA, Penguin Books UK, and India, 2006

(12/4) Intersectionality from the perspective of minority women (Komori):
1) What is the “intersectionality”?
its concept, backgrounds and function.
2) Intersectionality and the international community
3) Who are affected? Identity and minority communities

Suggested reading:
Intersectional feminism: what it means and why it matters right now.
https://www.unwomen.org/en/news/stories/2020/6/explainer-intersectional-feminism-what-it-means-and-why-it-matters

i) in the case of minority women in Japan
ii) in the case of Dalit women in South Asia
2) How do people address this problem?
Civil society organizations

Suggested readings:
Situations and challenges faced by minority women in Japan http://imadr.net/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2016/12/afb4085a070c5945387dab348d2e7f55.pdf
Caste and Gender Justice
https://idsn.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Caste-and-Gender-Justice-Low-Res2.pdf

(12/18) Gender-responsive planning (Miwa):
1) What is social and gender analysis?
2) Applying the most important tools of social and gender analysis

Required Reading:
Documents to be uploaded on the course website.

(1/8) Conclusion and pathways for SDGs (Miwa)
1) Reflection and discussion
2) How can we work as “change agent” for a sustainable world where diversity is fully respected.
